Missed and Disrupted Reunification Dinners
1. The Court ordered weekly reunification dinners to help rebuild the relationship
between Brittany (“Mother”) and our daughter, A.K. The order required
attendance unless there was an emergency and to make up any missed dinner
the following day.
2. Between January and August 2025, Brittany failed to attend, canceled, or cut
short the majority of those dinners.
o On January 10, 2025, Brittany rescheduled the court-ordered dinner to
Saturday morning. I arrived with both children at 9:00 a.m. as agreed; she
did not appear.
o On February 5, 2025, Brittany texted that she could not attend that
Wednesday’s dinner because of work. She proposed Thursday instead but
did not show up then either.
o On February 12, 2025, I waited with the children for thirty minutes;
Brittany never arrived. The next morning, she accused me by text of
“refusing make-up dinner” and threatened contempt even though she had
not appeared the night before.
o On April 20 (Easter) and May 11 (Mother’s Day), I offered dinners so she
could spend time with A.K.; she failed to participate.
o From June through August 2025, Brittany routinely ignored or canceled
Sunday dinners. On June 1, June 22, and June 29 she gave late-day
excuses. In July she wrote she “won’t be able to do dinners until I get back
to work,” missing July 6 and 13 entirely. On July 20 she left a planned
dinner early, saying she needed to return to Clanton before dark.
o On August 3, I sent multiple texts asking her what time she would meet
us; she never answered or appeared. On August 10, she agreed to meet
at 1:30 p.m. at Who’s Restaurant but never came. On August 17, she
refused to come to Alexander City, insisting I drive to Clanton. On August
24, she again failed to appear, citing childcare for her stepchildren.
3. Out of roughly thirty scheduled dinners from January through August, Brittany
missed more than half. Each absence or cancellation is documented in the
attached logs and text-message exhibits (Exhibits A–C).
2. Father’s Efforts to Facilitate Visitation and Holiday Compliance
1. I have complied with every visitation and counseling order and have gone
beyond what was required to promote contact between Brittany and the children.
2. Flexibility and Communication: I have kept all weekly dinner time slots open,
waited with the children each week, and repeatedly messaged Brittany asking if
she planned to attend. When she requested changes, I accommodated them. I
only insisted on following the written schedule after she began using my flexibility
to accuse me of “missing” dinners.
3. Special Occasions:
o On Mother’s Day 2025, I helped both children make gifts for their mother
and invited Brittany to have dinner with A.K. Although she came by to pick
up B.M., she declined to stay for the dinner and left early.
o On Easter 2025, I again offered for Brittany to join us for dinner so A.K.
could see her mother. Brittany did not attend.
o For summer 2025 visitation, I proactively offered Brittany an extra week
with B.M. during a work trip. She initially refused, then changed her mind; I
still allowed her to keep him that week. Counsel for both parties confirmed
the arrangement by email on June 2 2025 (Exhibit G).
4. Timely Exchanges and Compliance: I have never denied Brittany her visitation
with either child. When she arrived for B.M., I ensured punctual exchanges.
When she sought to extend time without notice, I reminded her of the court’s
schedule but did not refuse access.
5. Reunification Therapy Cooperation: After the Court ordered reunification
therapy for A.K. and Brittany, I cooperated fully. I provided A.K.’s calendar and
transportation and supported the sessions. I never contacted the therapist or
court to block Brittany’s participation.
6. My actions consistently reflect cooperation and the children’s best interests. The
documentary record (Exhibits E–G) confirms that any disruption of visitation
resulted from Brittany’s choices, not mine.
3. Inconsistencies in Mother’s Claims vs. Record
1. Claim of Missed Dinners: Brittany’s counsel alleged that I failed to attend
dinners that she herself canceled or skipped. For example, her attorney claimed
in February 2025 that I “missed” a rescheduled dinner when the texts show she
canceled and then failed to appear. The record demonstrates that I was present
and waiting each scheduled time (Exhibit H).
2. Claim of No Communication: Brittany has repeatedly asserted that I “did not
communicate plans.” Text-message records show the opposite. On September
14 2025 I texted Brittany that morning confirming the 1–6 p.m. Sunday dinner;
she did not respond and later claimed nothing had been planned. The standing
order itself fixed the time—no additional planning was needed (Exhibit H).
3. Claim of Alienation: Brittany accuses me of alienating A.K. from her. In reality, I
have encouraged every reasonable effort at contact. I never prevented
communication, and I have facilitated gifts, calls, and therapy sessions. Brittany
attended 1 of 12 soccer games, 2 of 16 football games, & 0 of 30 basketball
games.
4. Holiday Visitation: Brittany objects to setting aside forced holiday visitation for
A.K., ignoring the reality that A.K. has expressed severe distress about being
forced into visits. When Brittany suddenly demanded summer visitation with A.K.
on July 14 2025—after no contact for months—A.K. texted me, “No!! Please I’m
scared, why is this starting now. I don’t wanna go I’m gonna have a nervous
breakdown if I have to go.” (Exhibit I). Forcing holiday visitation under those
conditions would be emotionally harmful and contrary to the Court’s gradual
reunification plan.
4. Response to Allegations Concerning Reunification Therapy and Kelly Turner
1. Court Intent (July 31 2024 Hearing): Judge Perryman stated that before any
reunification therapy began, A.K. would have individual counseling followed by
joint sessions with her mother once appropriate. The transcript (pp. 26 ll. 20-23;
28 ll. 8-11, 14-19; 29 ll. 11-25; 30 ll. 1-6, filed Feb 11 2025) confirms this. The
later November 6 2024 order omitted that sequence and directed immediate joint
therapy with Kelly Turner. My subsequent filings sought to correct that mistake,
not obstruct therapy.
2. Full Cooperation: I complied with the November 6 order. I allowed Brittany to
select and schedule Kelly Turner, ensured A.K. attended both sessions, and
never canceled or interfered. Turner’s own February 12 2025 affidavit admits she
met only with Brittany and A.K., never with me, and relied solely on Brittany’s
statements. That record shows the process was one-sided through no fault of
mine.
3. Turner Withdrew Voluntarily: On February 14 2025 my counsel noticed Turner
for deposition so her statements could be examined. That same night at 11:46
p.m., Turner emailed:
“I did withdraw myself from the case via that email. I have not agreed to continue RT at
this time … If there is a court order that specifically indicates me to continue with RT, I
respectfully would decline.”
This email, attached as Exhibit N, proves Turner withdrew of her own accord, not
because of any interference by me.
4. My Immediate Follow-Up: I then filed
2025-02-13_MOTION_TO_STRIKE_AFFIDAVIT_OF_KELLY_TURNER.pdf and
2025-02-14_Motion_for_Reunification_Counselor_with_Exhibits_A_B_&_C.pdf,
requesting that Caroline Taylor, M.S., LPC—an independent reunification
specialist—be appointed so therapy could continue ethically and effectively.
5. Mischaracterization in Mother’s Objection: Agricola’s filings claim I
“sabotaged” therapy. Those allegations are false. Turner’s own affidavit and
withdrawal email demonstrate she ceased participation voluntarily after realizing
her process was compromised.
6. Consistency with Court’s Intent: All my actions aligned with Judge Perryman’s
stated goal—to proceed carefully and protect A.K.’s well-being. I supported
therapy, cooperated with scheduling, and immediately sought replacement
counseling when Turner withdrew.
5. Conclusion and Verification
I have complied in full with every order of this Court and have made continuous efforts
to encourage a healthy relationship between the children and their mother. The attached
records show that I have acted transparently, while the Petitioner has repeatedly failed
to participate and misrepresented facts.
For these reasons, I respectfully ask the Court to deny the Objection to Motion to Set
Aside Order Granting Court-Ordered Holiday Visitation.
